comments.commentBody:
No plan just inspiration. All that criticism of the Republican convention because it was short on details was just another campaign attack. Democrats never planned to provide any details of their own.

Obama wants to give you citizenship and community and call it a night.

I've come to believe that this president lives only in a hypothetical, ideal world, a world in the abstract, which he designs and invites his followers to enter. A "yes, we can!" world. A "You can do this!" world.

Do, what, exactly? Do what to bring unemployment down? Do what to get private industry investing in the US again? Do what to stimulate job growth that isn't subsidized by the government?

He cannot get down to details, the nuts and bolts of what needs to be done. He simply cannot. Never going to happen.

AAC - Apparently you weren't listening; or selectively listening.  President Obama said more last night than Mr. Romney has said since the beginning of his campaign.  Read the Republican platform, and then read the Democratic platform.  There's only one reasonable choice in November, and that's President Obama and Vice President Biden.

If you were dozing when the how part of Obama's plan you could listen to his address once more online. right here in the NYT.

You must have been dozubg..Just listen carefully next time.

It's nice that Obama believes we should work together, and lift each other up, and strengthen the middle class, Medicare, and Medicaid, and the military, and create manufacturing jobs, and clean energy jobs, and become energy independent, and give every child a collage education, and pay down the debt, and take care of our veterans, and eliminate poverty, house the homeless, feed the starving, and reduce health care costs, and eliminate global warming, and double CAFE standards, and and and... every other thing that everyone on earth can agree are intrinsically good things to do.

But when it comes to how he plans to actually do those things? His only solution is... hope.

Personally, I was hoping he had a detailed plan... and we see how well that worked out for me.
You missed it, with your focus on bobbles and prestige and power - like Romney.  This isn't about President Obama.  It's about "we" the people.  Not the party of ME.
You can always hope.
Times Up... Get ready to get off Air Force One.  But the good news is the golf course is right outside.
No more compromise, take no prisoners.
Ya can't go wrong quoting Lincoln.
In the end, a man's motives are second to his accomplishments.

The mosr powerful lines of President Obama's speech lie in this reference to his failings:

'And while I'm very proud of what we've achieved together,
I'm far more mindful of my own failings, knowing exactly what
Lincoln meant when he said, ''I have been driven to my knees many
times by the overwhelming conviction that I had no place else to
go.``

President Obama has my vote. He is the genuine article.

Exactly. And "organized labor" can effectively ask for a bigger piece of the pie, and "un-organized labor" cannot.
It boggles the mind that so many people don't seem to understand this nowadays. Didn't they study history?. Why do they think there was a labor movement in this country? People were living and working in horrible conditons at the start of the industrial revolution. Robber barons were keeping almost all of the profits from the tremedous increase in productivity to themselves, and paying pittances to the workers. Children worked in factories 12 hours a day. Working people had to organize to improve their working conditions, and to fight for a living wage above the level of industrial serfdom.
The income decline in the US goes right along with the decline in organized labor. People have forgotten the lessons of history.

A thoughtful reply, John.  I did forget about the amount of financing and equity seized by the government from Chrysler.  But here's the thing.  Say there was an orderly shutdown of GM and Chrysler.  People who bought GM cars and trucks now need to buy a new car.  Why wouldn't a company like Ford or Tata Motors or New Auto Company buy the assets, take over the union contracts and build new cars with these workers?  Build the same cars, new cars, other cars in the factories, buying parts from those same people, using the same workers in the same places?
Probably the greatest comment I have read on President Obama so far.

Um. Bush was responsible for TARP. (Obama simply extended it)Ford didn't take any auto bailout money, and GM owes the American people a TON of money we will probably never see along with shafting all their bond holders (i.e investors) GE pays zero taxes and now Immelt is ensconced in some government job. Gag! Where did you get your graduate degree from ? The University of Ignore the Facts?
Good Job President Obama!

I work in the auto industry, lost a good job during the crisis and 2 years later, after weathering the devastating recession in Michigan as a freelancer working for 30% of my former pay, was able to get a new auto industry job at 90% of what I used to make as the industry recovered. That's a victory in my book, considering how bad things were as of 2009.

I lived and followed the auto crisis events in real time. I also read the insider books that were published afterwards (Rattner's Overhaul, Paul Ingrassia's Crash Course, etc.) that explained what happened at levels well above my head. I have no doubt that President Obama and his team made wise decisions that ensured the survival of the US auto industry and protected the larger economy from collateral damage. The domestic auto industry is a popular punching bag, for both deserved and undeserved reasons. However, it is a necessary part of our economic fabric with large spillover economic benefits to communities nationwide and other industries that don't even realize how interconnected they are with the fates of GM, Ford, and Chrysler.

I appreciate President Obama's orientation towards choosing feasible and well-thought-out policies designed to ensure long-term success. As a Republican woman with a graduate business education who rarely votes Republican anymore due to the party's many repugnant policies, I encourage anyone undecided who reads this to vote for President Obama.

Thank you for considering my request.
What about Republicans' past ideas?
I think he knows that. Someone should tell Mitt Romney he's not Reagan...
Would you want "war criminals" at your convention?
Not acknowledging Bush or Cheney is an indicator of how the GOP operates: zero accountability for their own irresponsible behavior.

The 'other ' elephant in the room is the considerable cohort of Bush the Lessor's advisors, all of 'em waiting to resume their old positions of power and influence.

Who and wherever the turnip left unsqueezed, they'd like to come to grips.

I got a facinating e-mail from the Republican Party after President Clinton's speech comparing the success of his Presidency (a balanced budget, low unemployment, etc.) to the alleged failures of President Obama's. It then went on to state that we need a change to lower taxes, etc., reciting the predictable Republican rubbish that you can cut taxes and raise defense spending and somehow balance a budget. It ended with the usual exhortation to donate money to stop Obama.

Nowhere in the Republican e-mail did it mention that Clinton riased taxes, helping to balance the budget and drive prosperity, while President Bush II slashed taxes and started two unfunded wars that left us drowning in debt and in a near depression.

It is incredible that the Republicans can blame Obama for deficits and unemployment when it was their policies that directly took us from a balanced budget and low unemployment to red ink and staggering job losses.

The "elephant in the room" in Tampa was the notable absence of Bush and Cheney. It is instructive to see that the Democrats are not afraid to put their former president on stage.

Sorry, but I don't want to be a citizen of an Obama country. I've lived the last four years of his swill, and I don't want anymore.

'Citizen' is the term the French obamateers called themseves during the 'reign of terror,' also called the French Revolution to make it sound better.

The founding fathers would have known exactly what you and Obama mean by citizenship, partly because of their knowledge of French (and italian, and English and German etc.) political theorists.  Citizenship is the essence of republicanism--and it used to be the essence of (American) Republicanism.  Anyone who thinks that citizenship is some Unamerican French invention (see below) needs his head examined.

Tonight the president reminded us that we are not merely consumers and taxpayers. Indeed we are, more importantly, citizens. This is a far richer narrative than the narrow vision the republicans offer.

As we know the electorate has a short memory. Most people living today did not experience the depression of 1929-1941. They, the sons and daughters of WWII vets who became the best educated Americans ever. That gave them an economy unprecedented in history. They were also given credit unlike any other generation. They used it to run up more personal debt than their parents and grandparents would have ever thought possible.

Those that lived through the depression learned to be frugal, their children thought they had a bottomless piggy bank. That allowed the "Financial engineers" to find a way to help them acquire even more debt. Tthe big investment banks saw all that equity in their property. So the drive was on to relieve them of that equity. They convinced millions to refinance so they could buy SUVs, boats, entertainment centers and 4000 sq ft houses. Their forefathers would have seen right through those schemes.

Then to profit from these refies, they created Collateralized Debt Obligations, and the quants (statistical wizards) made the CDOs look good, and pressured the bond rating agencies to give them investment grade rates. Those failed and so did the banks.

Now the public thinks this can be reversed in two or three years The Republicans reinforce this attitude. It took 12 years and WWII to end the great depression and an unemployment rate that reached 25%. Obama's policies prevented this. Conservative prevarications make sure the public stays uneducated.

I suppose you're suggesting the proper version of the "American economy" is millionaires pulling as much money as possible out of people's pension funds and hiding it in offshore accounts?

Yes, let's keep doing that. That will certainly create jobs. Somehow.

Republicans can't point to a single time in history when cutting taxes on millionaires created middle class jobs while also cutting the deficit. Because it has never happened. Yet they continue to say that's how to help the economy. Oh, and by the way, let's cut health care for poor children, because that couldn't possibly cost us more in the long run....

As for "failed policies" -- nobody blames FDR for the state of the nation in 1936. Given that Obama was facing unemployment almost as bad, I think he's done extremely well -- particularly when you consider that the Tea Party shut down every single stimulus and jobs bill he proposed after they arrived in 2010 with no other goal than to limit government spending -- which during a recession is madness -- even conservative economists agree to that.

The President was handed a terrible mess. As was stated over 700,000 jobs per month were being lost. While the numbers lately of 150,000 job gains per month are not great they are certainly better than lossing over 700,000 jobs per month. That is a net change of 850,000 jobs per month.

There are many other things he was successful in doing. Increasing care to the veterans, making student loans cheaper, providing a mechanism for people without health insurance to obtain health insurance and ending the war in Iraq.

The restructuring of both GM and Chrysler have been successful and saved many jobs.

In addition, he helped stimulate the economy by lowering wage taxes for two years.

The economy needs when the middle class to become stronger. His policies are more likely to do that than the proposed policies of Governor Romney. Why, because the tax on labor is currently much higher than the tax on capital. Governor Romney proposed hugh tax cuts on capital, without anymore tax cuts on labor. This means that the middle class will continue to have shrinking real incomes so they will spend less. Without more middle class spending companies will not invest. Also Governor Romney as not stated how his policies will not increase the deficit.

Prersumably the really wealthy will continue to spend and invest, but much less of that spending and investing will be in the United States. Therefore the US economy will fall back into a decline.

He hasn't done a darn thing except saved the auto industry and passed a health care reform bill that will finally allow people with pre-existing conditions a possibility of coverage and invested money in crumbling infrastructure and killed Osama bin Laden? All while dealing with a Congress that, for the last 2 years, has voted 30 times to "repeal" health care (knowing that wouldn't actually have any effect) and has presented zero jobs bills of their own and zero replacement bills to solve health care?

I think he's been doing brilliantly, all things considered.

i  think you're missing something fundamental that's happened since 4 years ago, something called "citizens united" decided by the supreme court.  anger at that decision is a correct response, to put it mildly.

Obama: "I am not the candidate any more, I am the president"

Yeah we know, you have reminded us time after time after time over and over again. Go back to his previous speeches over the years and count the time he say "I" "me" "my".

Here is the stark contrast between the two conventions.  The GOP  is all "I, I, I" "me, me, me"  "mine, mine, mine" and the Dems are "We, We, We,"  "Us, Us, Us" and "Our, Our, Our" .  A party as self concerned and self focused as the GOP has no business running a country of "WE the people"

Apparently, you were listening to something other than what this president was saying on this evening.  I am surprised that you would still be listening to him at all with those well formulated negative attitudes.

you have hit the nail on the head. this will be the closest election since Bush in 2000. it will hinge on the democrats get out the vote operation. this is a crucial election and i urge democrats and independents to volunteer in their precincts to help people get to the polls and vote for President Obama.

Very clear 2012 election. Romney-destructive. Obama -hope for future and constructive ideas..

All it will take for success is a Republican effort to offer help and join the Obama team instead of trying to get rid of Obama!
The Republicans' real program: Let's go back to policies that got us into this mess in the first place. (Remember a definition of insanity: Repeating failed behavior, expecting a different result.)

To quote a previous article in the Times, "football is, in essence, a collision sport, with 100% chance of injury"...and this in a story about children playing.  NFL players weigh the risks vs. reward but there's little doubt young players knew the risk of dementia or depression to the extent it occurring.  The NFL at least needs to insure all players - for their lifetime.  They can well afford to do so.  Former NFL player, Dorsey Levens, has a new documentary out, Bell Rung, that takes a compelling look at the issue...the extent of the issue is only being touched upon.

Football already is a sport for the disadvantaged. Anyone who is at all familiar with the biographies of professional football players already knows that. Just as the military relies on a poverty draft, so too does football. As long as the United States is a society characterized by high levels of poverty -- and the current poverty rate is at its highest level in over 50 years -- there will be athletically talented, economically disadvantaged young men willing to incur the risks for the potential payoff (just as there will be recruits for the military). I say all this as a rabid fan of the sport, whose fascination with it, like several other commentators here, does not derive from its violence, but rather from its artistry. It is nonetheless very difficult to reconcile my love for the game with the obvious physical toll it inflicts on those who play it and the manner in which it exploits disadvantaged (most typically African American) youth. I would have no problem if the NFL were to devise rules that significantly diminished the violence of the game, but maintained it as a showcase for athletic artistry.

GM as you knew it is dead. The new GM, which coincidentally has the same name as the old GM, has been reborn with almost no debt, a new labor agreement that is much less union seniority centric, and - for a time - without much public shareholders. His promises were kept, alright. Even though the unions accepted a lighter contract, they still are in force and have their fair share of the pie. I like the beginning of his speech. Can't there be a continued conversation without rhetoric. Can't the NYT, twitter, facebook, someone host a conversation of people who don't want to just win an election, but who are grounded in reality?

You want to extend Social Security? Fine. According to the SSA, retirement age for SS was 65 but the life expectancy was around 60; about 13 years after retirement is when benefits were going to start. Now compare that to 1990: around 17-18 years after 65 is when the average expectancy of a person. Adding a year to every 10, there's about seven years difference between now and then for retirees over 65. (http://tiny.cc/scy8jw). Tomorrow, Rep. Ryan should introduce a bill that raises the retirement age to 72 and the President should vow to sign it. It's fair, it's consistent with the pricinples of the law, and it's a step towards a solution. Law #2: No more borrowing from the Medicare and SS funds. Cut the federal government off. See the affects not in 10 years but in two. Then come back to the table, and figure out some more.
This line brought me to tears.  President Obama not only has my vote but my support in getting him re-elected.

What's your plan, Bob? And what is Romney's? It sure isn't double down on trickle down. The country runs best when the middle class is empowered - no doubt about it. President Obama explained that.

We will see if the Republican's are willing to meet him halfway. And that won't be decided until they find out if they can have the White House back.
That stood out to me as well. Small understated things that are actually the tips of a huge iceberg of difference. Evolution and complexity vs. rigidity and oversimplification.

I was struck by the powerful references to the notice of the "citizen" in the usa.  very nice (and subtle) touch.  and also by the female pronoun use.  these two candidates could hardly be much different.
